body: Good job! You've added all the required questions and meet all the specifications. :clap:

Your codes are clean and easy to read! :+1:

In advanced, you could also add a documentation in every method that is important. This is a good practice that professional android developer did.

I have a shortcut for you in adding a documentation:
- In Android Studio, there is a shortcut when adding a documentation. Just type `/**` above the method and then hit `Enter`.
- In additional, you could also add a description about the method (parameter and return value).

### Example
```
/**
  * This method is used to calculate the score and display the result 
  */
```

When comparing with a string, it will be better if you use an `equalsIgnoreCase` instead of using an `equals` method. It will handle the answer with uppercase, lowercase, or both of them. So, if the user fills the answer with `good`, it still counts as a correct answer.

You can use a `trim()` to remove any trailing spaces from the user input. It will make the validation perfect.
```
String Delhi1 = ET.getText().toString().trim();

```
